overview: Deposit protection schemes - the 3 official schemes, information landlords must give tenants, if your landlord doesn't protect your deposit, disputes and advice
title: Tenancy deposit protection

table.body:
If you rent your home on an assured shorthold tenancy that started after 6 April 2007, your landlord must place your deposit in 1 of 3 tenancy deposit protection (TDP) schemes:

- [Deposit Protection Service](http://www.depositprotection.com/ "Deposit Protection Scheme"){:rel="external"}
- [MyDeposits](http://www.mydeposits.co.uk/ "MyDeposits"){:rel="external"}
- [Tenancy Deposit Scheme](http://www.tds.gb.com/ "Tenancy Deposit Scheme"){:rel="external"}

These government-backed schemes guarantee you'll get your deposit back if you:

- meet the terms of your tenancy agreement 
- don’t damage the property
- pay your rent and bills

Your landlord or letting agent must put your deposit in the scheme within 14 days of getting it.

##At the end of your tenancy
If you and your landlord agree how much deposit you'll get back, it must be returned to you within 10 days of the tenancy ending.

If you're in a dispute with your landlord, then your deposit is protected in the TDP until the issue is sorted.

##Holding deposits
Your landlord doesn't have to protect a holding deposit (money you pay to ‘hold’ a property before an agreement is signed). However, once you become a tenant, the holding deposit becomes a deposit, which they must protect.

##Deposits made by a third party
Your landlord must use a TDP scheme even if your deposit is paid by someone else, like a rent deposit scheme or your parents.

*[TDP]: Tenancy deposit protection
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Within 14 days of getting your deposit, your landlord must tell you:

- the address of the rented property 
- how much deposit you've paid
- how the deposit is protected
- the name and contact details of the TDP scheme and its dispute resolution service
- their (or the letting agency's) name and contact details
- the name and contact details of any third party that's paid the deposit
- why they would keep some or all of the deposit
- how to apply to get the deposit back
- what to do if you can't get hold of the landlord at the end of the tenancy
- what to do if there's a dispute over the deposit

*[TDP]: Tenancy deposit protection
table.title: Information landlords must give tenants

##Getting your deposit back
If you think your landlord hasn't used a TDP scheme when they should have, you can apply to a county court. 

^[Get legal advice](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "Find a legal adviser"){:rel="external"} before applying to court.^

If the court finds your landlord hasn’t protected your deposit, it can order the person holding the deposit to either:

- repay it to you
- pay it into a custodial TDP scheme’s bank account within 14 days

The court may also order the landlord to pay you 3 times the deposit within 14 days of making the order. 

^[Search for a county court.](http://hmctscourtfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS "Find a court"){:rel="external"}^

##At the end of the tenancy
If your landlord doesn't use a TDP scheme when they have to, the court may also decide that you won't have to leave the property when the tenancy ends.

*[TDP]: Tenancy deposit protection
table.title: If your landlord doesn't protect your deposit

table.body:
##If there’s a dispute over a deposit
If you disagree with your landlord about how much deposit should be returned, then your TDP scheme offers a free dispute resolution service.

##If you can't contact the landlord
If your landlord is registered with the Deposit Protection Service (DPS) you can [make a single claim](https://www.depositprotection.com/ "Deposit Protection Service"){:rel="external"} to recover the deposit.

If the scheme can't get in contact with the landlord, you get your deposit back.

If your landlord is registered with [MyDeposits](http://www.mydeposits.co.uk/tenants/get-started/register-a-dispute/ "Raise a dispute with MyDeposits"){:rel="external"} or the [Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS)](http://www.thedisputeservice.co.uk/raise-a-dispute.html "Raise a dispute with TDS"){:rel="external"} you can ‘raise a dispute' to recover the deposit.

The scheme's insurer will refund your deposit if the dispute resolution service agrees this is fair.

*[TDP]: Tenancy deposit protection
